;

;随着美国经济的崛起，周一基准 10 年期国债收益率升至 5% 以上，并创 2007 年以来最高水平经济形势导致投资者预计利率将在较长时间内保持高位。

;

;收益率上升和中东更广泛冲突的风险相结合，在充满大型经济活动的一周之初，令市场情绪恶化。限制盈利和关键数据，并推动全球股市跌至七个月低位。

;

;10年期国债收益率达到5.012%，当天上涨8.6个基点，这是市场经济复苏的最新迹象。全球债券抛售的规模也受到政府债务增加、全球债券供应增加以及前景不确定的推动，这导致投资者要求更高的溢价来持有期限较长的债券。

;

;"5从经济角度来看，%只是另一个数字。但就投资者而言，它引起了共鸣，”大和资本首席经济学家 Chris Scicluna 表示。

;

;“我不认为这是一个转折点，但它是一个转折点。提醒我们已经经历了创纪录的紧缩，就美联储而言，这也提醒他们，他们无法完全确定迄今为止的紧缩政策有多少已经传导至实体经济，还有多少即将到来，”他说。

;

;债券收益率的飙升已经收紧了货币条件，而央行无需采取任何行动，从而允许;美联​​储;表示其可能会在下周的政策会议上按兵不动。

;

;事实上，期货暗示美联储完成本周期紧缩政策的可能性约为 70%，并考虑从明年 5 月开始降息。

;

;股市估值的上涨也挑战了股票估值，并拖累大多数主要股指走低周，而美国股市波动的 VIX“恐惧指数”;(.VIX);触及 3 月份以来的最高水平。

;

;MSCI 全球指数;(.MIWD00000PUS ); 最后下跌 0.2%，为 3 月底以来的最低水平，当时席卷全球银行业的动荡开始消退。

;

;在欧洲，STOXX 600 ;(.STOXX); 下跌 0.5%，也处于七个月低点，对利率敏感的房地产股 < a href="https://www.reuters.com/markets/quote/.SX86P" target="_blank">;(.SX86P); 跌至 2012 年以来的最低水平。

;

;美国股指期货最后下跌约 0.4%。

;

;中东战争也是投资者关注的焦点。华盛顿;周末警告;：作为盟友，美国在中东的利益;以色列袭击加沙; 与黎巴嫩边境的冲突加剧。

;

;微软的巨型上限;( MSFT.O);、Alphabet ;(GOOGL.O);、亚马逊;(AMZN.O); 和元平台;(META.O); 本周所有报告收益。 IBM ;(IBM.N); 和 Intel ;(INTC.O); 也在考虑范围内。

;

;利润应由以下方面的实力支撑：本周美国国内生产总值 (GDP) 数据显示，消费者需求预计第三季度年化增长率将达到 4.2%，名义年化增长率可能高达 7%。

;

;美国的优异表现支撑了尽管日本干预的威胁将其限制在 150.00 日元左右，至少目前是这样。美元最后交易价格为 149.93 日元，略低于近期峰值 150.16。

;

;日本国债收益率也在;猜测;日本央行正在讨论进一步调整其收益率曲线控制政策，该政策可能会在其10 月 31 日的政策会议。

;

;欧元小幅上涨至 1.0607 美元，而瑞士法郎因过去几周的避险情绪而受益，稳定在 0.8924 美元兑 1 美元。欧元兑欧元小幅走软，为每欧元 0.94645。

;

;欧洲央行将于本周晚些时候举行会议，预计将维持利率在 4% 不变。投资者将关注欧洲央行行长克里斯蒂娜·拉加德关于全球债券收益率上升可能如何影响欧元区货币政策前景的任何信号。

;

;“鉴于收益率进一步上升，我们”最近，自上次会议以来发生的地缘政治事件，我认为我们需要等待，看看她的语气是什么，以及她是否仍然有紧缩倾向，”大和的 Scicluna 表示。

;

;黄金上周也因避险资金流入而触及 5 月份以来的最高点，目前持平于每盎司 1,980 美元左右。

;

;油价小幅下滑，布伦特原油下跌 0.26%，至每桶 91.80 美元.

;

;尽管石油市场上更大的消息是;雪佛龙; ;(CVX.N); 表示同意收购 Hess ;(HES.N); 购买价值 530 亿美元的股票。

;;迪玛·阿拉姆达尼和她的家人是数十万加沙人逃离南方的原因之一，以避免以色列对加沙城的持续空袭。一家人在汗尤尼斯的临时避难所安顿下来，但 10 月 17 日夜间，以色列喷气式飞机对避难所进行了大规模轰炸。阿拉姆达尼、她的兄弟和两个表弟在爆炸中幸存，但也受了一些伤。她剩下的13名亲戚，包括她的父母、7个兄弟姐妹和4名叔叔的家人，就没那么幸运了。;
;

;当以色列军队告诉加沙城海滩难民营的巴勒斯坦人：逃往南方，因为那里更安全，18 岁的迪玛·阿尔·拉姆达尼 (Dima Al-Lamdani) 的家人祈祷他们能逃离无情的空袭。

;

;但几天后，拉姆达尼 (Dima Al-Lamdani) 被迫在临时太平间辨认亲人的尸体。在南部城市汗尤尼斯。她说，她在以色列空袭中失去了父母、七个兄弟姐妹和四名叔叔的家人。

;

;“他们告诉我们撤离你的住所并前往汗尤尼斯，因为那里很安全......他们背叛了我们并轰炸了我们，”她说。

;

;她说她的家人和她叔叔的家人乘坐两辆车穿越加沙，该地区曾面临;巴勒斯坦激进组织哈马斯 10 月 7 日对以色列发动袭击后最猛烈的轰炸，造成约 1,400 人死亡，劫持了 200 多名人质。

;

;Lamdani 的家人住在汗尤尼斯 (Khan Younis) 的一个临时避难所，她说：“凌晨 4.30，我醒了，和我的姨妈坐在一起喝咖啡。突然我在中间醒来废墟。我周围的每个人都在尖叫，所以我也尖叫。”

;

;Lamdani 的一侧脸被擦伤并瘀伤，10 月 17 日在太平间寻找家人后，她说，只有她自己兄弟和两个年轻的表兄弟幸存下来，但受了一些伤。

;

;“这是一场噩梦。它永远不会从我的记忆中抹去，”她说。“我有一个16岁的妹妹。他们把我的名字写在包裹她身体的白床单上，他们以为那是我。”

;

;以色列军方发言人表示：“以色列国防军一直鼓励加沙地带北部居民向南迁移，不要留在加沙城内哈马斯恐怖目标附近。

;

;”但是，最终，哈马斯在整个加沙地带的平民中根深蒂固。因此，无论哈马斯的目标出现在哪里，以色列国防军都会对其进行打击，以挫败该组织的恐怖主义能力，同时采取可行的预防措施，减轻对未参与其中的平民的伤害”

;

;加沙卫生部门表示，以色列两周的轰炸已造成 5000 多人死亡，15000 多人受伤。

;

;10 月 7 日后，以色列总共实施了加沙地带遭到封锁，该​​地区 230 万人的水、食物、药品和燃料即将耗尽。

;

;周一，援助人员和安全消息人士称，;援助卡车;从埃及进入拉法过境点前往加沙。 ;拉法;是进出加沙的主要过境点，不与以色列接壤。

;

;联合国官员表示，每天需要大约 100 辆卡车才能满足加沙的基本需求。周六和周日，有 34 辆卡车通过。

;

;在检查援助物资的程序上发生争执以及边境加沙一侧的轰炸导致救援物资滞留在埃及后，周六开始通过拉法运送人道主义物资。< /p>;

;雪佛龙;(CVX.N); 周一表示同意收购 Hess ;(HES.N); 以 530 亿美元的股票收购，这是继埃克森美孚之后美国最大石油公司中第二次拟议的大型合并;(XOM.N); 本月早些时候出价 600 亿美元收购先锋自然资源公司。

;

;拟议的交易加剧了雪佛龙与世界第一大石油公司雪佛龙之间的竞争。埃克森美孚是美国第二大石油和天然气生产商，这将使其成为其在圭亚那的更大竞争对手的不同寻常的合作伙伴，因为赫斯与中国的中海油正在共同开发在新兴的拉丁美洲生产商的钻探业务。

;< p>;这笔交易还表明雪佛龙计划继续增加对化石燃料的投资，因为石油需求依然强劲，而且大型生产商在多年投资不足后通过收购来补充库存。

;

;雪佛龙已发行 1.025 股其股票持有的每股 Hess 股票的价格为 171 美元，这意味着该股的最后收盘价溢价约 4.9%。交易总价值为 600 亿美元，包括债务。

;

;雪佛龙股价盘前下跌 3%。加拿大皇家银行分析师表示，他们对交易时机感到惊讶，并预计该公司将在埃克森美孚收购先锋的大型交易后等待时机 ;(PXD.N);。

;

;圭亚那凭借近年来的巨大发现，已成为主要石油生产国，使其成为拉丁美洲最著名的生产国之一，仅次于巴西和墨西哥。

;

;埃克森美孚及其合作伙伴赫斯和中国海油;(0883.HK ）;是该国唯一活跃的石油生产商。他们的项目预计到 2027 年产量将达到 120 万桶/日。

;

;赫斯公司首席执行官约翰·赫斯预计将在 2024 年上半年交易完成后加入雪佛龙董事会。

;

;赫斯公司首席执行官约翰·赫斯预计将加入雪佛龙董事会。 >;

;两家公司表示，合并后的公司预计将比雪佛龙当前的五年指导更快、更长久地增长产量和自由现金流。

;

;雪佛龙表示，交易完成后，其打算将其股票回购计划增加 25 亿美元，达到 200 亿美元年度范围的上限，这表明对未来能源价格及其现金生成充满信心。

;

;高盛是赫斯的首席顾问，而摩根则Stanley 是雪佛龙的首席顾问。

;追踪华尔街主要股指的期货周一暴跌，因为基准美国 10 年期国债收益率触及备受关注的 5% 大关，引发大型股抛售股票。

;

;;收益率;该票据触及了 2007 年 7 月的里程碑，上周它曾短暂地试图突破这一里程碑。最后为 5.0144%。

;

;“当投资者能够通过政府债券等安全资产获得 5% 的年回报率时，他们就不太可能在风险较高的投资中冒险，”高级投资分析师 Marios Hadjikyriacos外汇经纪商 XM 在一份报告中表示。

;

;“除了提供有吸引力的股票替代品之外，较高的债券收益率还使企业承担债务的成本更高，从而限制了扩张的范围以及最终的盈利增长."

;

;包括 Apple 在内的超级电容 ;(AAPL.O); 、微软 ;(MSFT.O);、Alphabet ;(GOOGL.O);，Nvidia ;(NVDA.O);，元平台;(META.O); 和 Amazon.com ;(AMZN.O)< /a>; 在盘前交易中下跌 0.6% 至 1.5%。

;

;焦点还将继续放在繁忙的一周财报上，“七强”股票中有四只将于本周晚些时候公布财报，这些股票的涨幅推动了股市的上涨。标准普尔 500 指数将在 2023 年走高，而其他指数则落后。

;

;芯片制造商英特尔 ;(INTC.O);，石油巨头埃克森美孚;(XOM.N)< /a>;、通用汽车 ;(GM.N); 是其他一些公司本周公布季度业绩。

;

;根据 LSEG 的数据，标准普尔 500 指数成分股中的 86 家公司迄今为止已经公布了第三季度的收益，其中 78% 的业绩超出了分析师的预期。总体而言，第三季度盈利可能同比增长 1%。

;

;与此同时，以色列;连夜对加沙进行空袭;，总理本雅明·内塔尼亚胡召集高级将领和战时内阁会议，评估不断升级的冲突。

;

;紧张局势加剧，加上利率预期上升导致债券收益率飙升，上周华尔街股市走低，标普 500 指数;(.SPX); 下跌 1.26%，芝加哥期权交易所波动率指数 ;(.VIX); 收于 3 月 24 日以来的最高水平。

;

;基准股指较 7 月底触及年内最高点下跌 8%，但仍上涨 10%

;

;投资者本周将密切关注美国 GDP 数据，因为预计第三季度经济将强劲增长 4.2%，这可能需要收紧货币政策。

;

; p>;

;美联储主席杰罗姆·鲍威尔将在周三的一次活动中发表简短的介绍性讲话，但自周六开始联邦公开市场委员会 (FOMC) 禁售期以来，他不太可能就货币政策发表讲话。< /p>;

;共和党人的党派内讧已导致美国众议院瘫痪三周，周一将再次开始，试图挑选一位新议长来领导众议院，并解决以色列、乌克兰和联邦政府的资金需求。

;

;右翼强硬派和更主流的共和党人之间的派系冲突导致了前议长凯文·麦卡锡 (Kevin McCarthy) 于 10 月 3 日被罢黜，两位潜在继任者的领导权争夺也落空：众议院共和党第二号人物 ;Steve Scalise; 和杰出的;保守派吉姆·乔丹;。

;

;;领导层真空;阻碍了国会的行动，因为国会面临11月17日的最后期限，通过延长联邦机构资金来避免政府关闭，以及总统乔·拜登批准军事援助的请求for Israel and Ukraine.

;

;"This is probably one of the most embarrassing things I've seen," House Foreign Affairs Committee Chairman Michael McCaul, a Republican, told ABC's "This Week" on Sunday. "We're essentially shut down as a government."

;

;The task of choosing a new Republican nominee for the job of House speaker begins again on Monday at 6:30 pm EST (2230 GMT), when nine declared candidates, including No. 3 House Republican Tom Emmer, will appear at a closed-door candidate forum.

;

;McCarthy has endorsed Emmer, stressing his experience in working to marshal party votes on major legislation since January, when Republicans became the majority party in the House.

;

;"This is not a moment in time to play around with learning on the job," McCarthy told NBC's "Meet the Press", although he added: "It's going to be an uphill battle."

;

;With a narrow majority of 221-212 in the House, it is not clear whether any Republican can get the 217 votes needed to claim the speaker's gavel.

;

;Any candidate nominated by the party conference can afford to lose no more than four Republicans when the full House votes, and the conference is split over spending cuts, Ukraine funding and other hot-button issues.

;

;Matt Gaetz, the Republican who initiated McCarthy's ouster, complained to reporters that Jordan was "knifed by secret ballot" after the conference voted late last week to end his bid for speaker.

;

;

;Democrats described Jordan as a dangerous extremist and opponents inside his own party were angered by a pressure campaign from his supporters that resulted in death threats.

;

;Seven of the nine new candidates for speaker - Jack Bergman, Byron Donalds, Kevin Hern, Mike Johnson, Dan Meuser, Gary Palmer and Pete Sessions - voted to overturn Trump's 2020 loss to President Joe Biden on the day that Trump supporters assaulted Congress on Jan. 6, 2021.

;

;The two remaining candidates, Emmer and Austin Scott, did not vote to block certification of the election results.

;

;House Republicans have been embroiled in chaos all year. McCarthy needed an agonizing 15 votes to win the speaker's gavel in January, and along the way had to made concessions that enabled a single member to force a vote for his removal.

;

;That happened this month when eight Republicans forced him out after he passed legislation with Democratic support that averted a partial government shutdown.

;

;Investors say the tumult has contributed to market turbulence and Biden has urged Republicans to sort out their problems.

; Mon, 23 Oct 2023 18:25:03 +0800 Strong ad sales, stable enterprise spending wind beneath Big Tech earningshttps://reuters.com/article/tech-results/strong-ad-sales-stable-enterprise-spending-wind-beneath-big-tech-earnings-idUSKBN31N0IF
;;2023-10-23T10:05:25Z;
;;
;;The logos of Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google are seen in a combination photo from Reuters files. REUTERS/File Photos/File Photo;
;

;US technology giants are likely to post their strongest quarterly revenue growth in at least a year as their legacy businesses stabilized, but investors looking for signs of a boost from artificial intelligence (AI) may be disappointed.

;

;Microsoft ;(MSFT.O);, Google-parent Alphabet ;(GOOGL.O);, Facebook-parent Meta Platforms ;(META.O); and Amazon ;(AMZN.O); are expected to have built on the recovery in their enterprise software and digital ads businesses as professional and consumer spending stayed resilient despite an uncertain global economy.

;

;The quartet's shares have rallied -- between Microsoft's 36% and Meta's 157% -- this year, boosting their combined market value to over $6 trillion and lifting the benchmark S&P 500 index ;(.SPX);.

;

;"After a year where enterprise spend was held down by concerns about the economy, we're heading into a year where those concerns are slowly subsiding, making for a more stable spending environment in enterprise software and advertising," said Gil Luria, senior software analyst at DA Davidson.

;

;While enterprise demand stabilized for legacy products, that has not extended to cloud computing, the mainstay for Microsoft and Amazon. The duo likely just barely budged off their previous quarter's record-low cloud growth rates.

;

;Microsoft, though, is likely to flag some wins from its investment in OpenAI and integrating the technology across its products, analysts said. The company had promised ;aggressive spending; to meet demand for its AI products.

;

;RBC Capital Market estimates Microsoft will clock over $3 billion in revenue from generative AI offerings this fiscal.

;

;For others, such AI investments, like buying expensive Nvidia ;(NVDA.O); chips, may hurt their bottom lines in the short term.

;

;"It's probably not going to be material to revenue until 2025 because enterprises are still figuring out their generative AI strategy," RBC analyst Rishi Jaluria said.

;

;On Tuesday, Microsoft is likely to report a nearly 9% rise in first-quarter revenue, according to LSEG data, driven by strength in its enterprise productivity software business.

;

;Its costs, however, are estimated to have jumped 8.4%, the most in a year.

;

;On the same day, Alphabet is expected to post a 10% rise in quarterly sales. Revenue from Google Services, which includes YouTube, Search and the sale of apps, is expected to have grown by 8.5%.

;

;Alphabet and Meta are set to benefit from an uptick in digital ad sales ahead of the holiday-shopping season.

;

;Last month, media research and investment firm Magna raised its forecast for US ad spending growth to 5.2%, from 4.2%, for calendar 2023. It expects digital ad sales to rise 9.6% in the period.

;

;Meta is expected to report its quarterly revenue increased by more than a fifth, the most in two years, and lay out its AI plans, after unveiling a ;series of AI ad tools; last month.

;

;But cloud computing growth for all the companies is expected to show little improvement as clients look for ways to optimize their infrastructure costs.

;

;Market leaders Amazon Web Services and Microsoft's Azure likely grew by 12.4% and 26.2%, respectively (Azure estimates from Visible Alpha) in the quarter.

;

;While they will have inched up from their record-low growth rates in the previous quarter, Google will take their place with an estimated 25.7% growth.

;

;Amazon, however, is expected to be shielded by strong retail sales, thanks to a strong labor market. The e-commerce giant is projected to post an 11.3% rise in revenue on Thursday.

;

;Meta reports on Wednesday and Apple will round off Big Tech earnings with results next week, on Nov. 2.

; Mon, 23 Oct 2023 18:25:03 +0800 Sam Bankman-Fried“s lawyers avoid challenges to “cartoon“ villain imagehttps://reuters.com/article/usa-bankmanfried/sam-bankman-frieds-lawyers-avoid-challenges-to-cartoon-villain-image-idUSKBN31N0IJ
;;2023-10-23T10:11:19Z;
;;
;;Former FTX Chief Executive Sam Bankman-Fried, who faces fraud charges over the collapse of the bankrupt cryptocurrency exchange, leaves following a hearing at Manhattan federal court in New York City, US January 3, 2023. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo;
;

;Sam Bankman-Fried's lawyers have complained that prosecutors at his ;fraud trial; are portraying the FTX cryptocurrency exchange founder as a "cartoon of a villain," but have done little to counter unflattering depictions of him offered to the jury by his former colleagues.

;

;In cross-examining former members of his inner circle who have pleaded guilty and testified for the prosecution, defense lawyers generally has avoided challenging their accounts of Bankman-Fried angrily snapping at colleagues who questioned key company decisions. They also did not challenge testimony by one of the witnesses that his quirky persona was mostly an act.

;

;Defense lawyers will have a chance to put forward a ;competing narrative; when they present their case, beginning as soon as Thursday. But the testimony presented by the prosecution that has painted a negative portrait of the defendant's character, if it remains unchallenged, could make jurors more willing to convict Bankman-Fried, according to experts.

;

;"Even though it doesn't go directly to guilt or innocence, it might create a bad impression," said Jordan Estes, a former federal prosecutor in Manhattan who is now a partner at law firm Kramer Levin. "It's easier to convict someone that you might not like as much."

;

;Federal prosecutors in Manhattan have said Bankman-Fried looted billions of dollars in FTX customer funds to prop up his crypto-focused trading firm Alameda Research, make speculative venture investments and donate more than $100 million to US political campaigns to burnish his image in Washington.

;

;Bankman-Fried has pleaded not guilty to two counts of fraud and five counts of conspiracy. He could spend decades in prison if convicted.

;

;In his Oct. 4 opening statement to the jury, defense lawyer Mark Cohen said Bankman-Fried "overlooked" risk management while building FTX and Alameda, which declared bankruptcy in November 2022 following a wave of withdrawals by customers. But Cohen said Bankman-Fried did not intend to steal the customers' money.

;

;Allowing specific unfavorable accounts by prosecution witnesses to go unchallenged on cross-examination could be a strategic choice by the defense, according to experts. That is because challenging such testimony could remind jurors of the negative anecdotes relayed by the witnesses.

;

;"If they ask a lot of questions about it on cross, it's giving more air time to an issue that isn't necessarily helpful to them," said Rachel Maimin, a former federal prosecutor in Manhattan who is now a partner at law firm Lowenstein Sandler.

;

;Bankman-Fried's best shot at establishing a positive impression of his character may be to take the witness stand himself, some experts said. His lawyers have said the defendant is considering doing so.

;

;During opening statements, Cohen told jurors of the prosecutors: "They'd have you think he was quite the villain, or, more precisely, almost a cartoon of a villain. But the evidence will give you a very different context. The evidence will show that Sam was someone who worked very hard to try to build things, not harm them."

;

;The descriptions of Bankman-Fried by the prosecution's three star witnesses contradict the 31-year-old former billionaire's pre-arrest reputation as a ;nerdy do-gooder; who wanted to be a responsible actor in the rough-and-tumble crypto space.

;

;So far, two key prosecution witnesses have testified about instances in which Bankman-Fried disparaged colleagues who disagreed with him, particularly about financial issues at the heart of the criminal charges.

;

;Nishad Singh, FTX's former engineering chief, testified last week that when he ;confronted Bankman-Fried; about marketing and venture spending that he found excessive, Bankman-Fried said it was "people like me sowing seeds of doubt in the company's decisions that were the real insidious problem here."

;

;"It was pretty humiliating," said Singh, who has pleaded guilty to fraud charges.

;

;Caroline Ellison, Alameda's onetime chief executive officer and Bankman-Fried's former girlfriend, ;testified; that when one employee raised objections to bribing Chinese officials to get Alameda funds in the country unfrozen, Bankman-Fried used a profanity in telling her to shut up.

;

;Ellison, who has also pleaded guilty to fraud, said Bankman-Fried told her that his signature sloppy dress and wild mop of curly locks was an "important part of FTX's image."

;

;Cohen has said outside the jury's presence that prosecutors were presenting "cumulative evidence portraying our client as a very dirty person."

;

;Cohen also said prosecutors showed a document Bankman-Fried wrote to try to resolve a dispute between two colleagues only to imply that he is "some sort of crazy person." In the document, Bankman-Fried ;10 times in a row; wrote the phrase, "Being aligned and always doing whatever you think is best for the company."

;

;Two Texas jurisdictions will consider measures this week to outlaw the act of transporting another person along their roads for an abortion, part of a strategy by conservative activists to further restrict abortion since the US Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade.

;

;Commissioners in Lubbock County are slated to vote on the proposal on Monday. A few hours north, the Amarillo City Council on Tuesday will weigh its own such law, which could lead to a future council or city-wide vote.

;

;Lubbock and Amarillo are the biggest jurisdictions of the 10 places in Texas that have considered restrictions on abortion-related transportation since the June 2022 end of Roe, which had granted a nationwide right to abortion. Five cities and counties in the state have passed bans.

;

;Lubbock and Amarillo are both traversed by major highways that connect Texas, which has one of the county's most stringent abortion laws, to neighboring New Mexico, where abortion is legal.

;

;Anti-abortion activists backing the proposals say they are meant to bolster Texas' existing abortion ban, which allows private citizens to sue anyone who provides or "aids or abets" an abortion after six weeks of pregnancy.

;

;Advocates of reproductive rights say the measures could deter people from seeking abortions or helping others get abortions, even though there is no clear way to enforce the bans.采用这些措施的五个司法管辖区尚未报告任何违规行为。 Their reliance on citizen enforcement makes them difficult to challenge in court.

;

;The greater impact of the ordinances so far appears to be how each side is using them to galvanize voters and pursue bigger political goals heading into an election year in which abortion remains a hot-button issue.

;

;The campaign to ban abortion-related transit in Texas was started by Mark Lee Dickson, a Christian pastor who began pushing communities to outlaw abortion by declaring themselves ;"sanctuary cities for the unborn"; in 2019.

;

;Dickson travels widely to pitch his measures. He also mobilizes supporters to unseat local leaders who oppose the proposals, with the aim of electing officials who will also push other far-right policies.

;

;He took that approach in Odessa's city elections in 2022 after the council initially blocked one of his "sanctuary city for the unborn" proposals. Dickson responded by marshalling support for council candidates who pledged to approve it.

;

;Once elected, the candidates he backed not only declared Odessa a "sanctuary city," but also adopted the state's first abortion transport ban and took other steps Dickson supported, such as rejecting state and federal COVID-19-related mandates.

;

;"This isn't over just when you address one issue," Dickson said in an interview.

;

;He plans to be at the meetings in Lubbock and Amarillo this week.

;

;Lubbock County Commissioner Jason Corley said he was inspired to bring the transport ban to a vote on Monday after hearing Dickson promote it at Lubbock's Constitutionalist Society. Corley, who has supported Dickson's work for years, said he expected the measure to pass.

;

;Not all backers of abortion restrictions support Dickson's transport bans, however.

;

;Amarillo Mayor Cole Stanley said he supported Dickson's "sanctuary city" movement, but is concerned that the transport bans rely on civil enforcement and do not clarify what local authorities are expected to do, potentially entangling the city in investigations brought by private actors.

;

;The debates over the transport bans are spurring new shows of support for abortion access.

;

;In Lubbock County, Kimberleigh Gonzalez is organizing a local Facebook group of 1,100 reproductive rights supporters to show their opposition to the measure at Monday's meeting.

;

;The group formed after Lubbock voters ;approved a "sanctuary city" ordinance; backed by Dickson in May 2021. Each new attack on reproductive rights "brings us together a little more tightly," Gonzalez said.

;

;"Since 2021, I know a lot of people personally that are involved that weren't before, and it just continues to grow and strengthen," she said.

;

;Abortion rights supporters, including four abortion funds in Texas, said they expected the transport bans to backfire on the anti-abortion movement by galvanizing political participation from abortion rights advocates in the lead-up to next year's presidential election.

;

;"We're going to make sure that there are political and electoral consequences for this," said Rachel O'Leary Carmona, executive director of the Women's March activist organization.
